search_information.query_displayed: how accurate are covid rapid tests

related_questions.question: Are COVID rapid tests still accurate?
related_questions.snippet: Results from rapid, at-home antigen tests are often available within 15 minutes. If you test positive, you are very likely to be infected. However, there is a higher chance of false negatives with antigen tests, which means that you could test negative and still have an active infection.
related_questions.title: COVID tests: Do at-home tests work on newer variants?

related_questions.question: Can a rapid COVID test be wrong?
related_questions.snippet: Rarely, COVID-19 rapid antigen tests can give false-positive results. False-positive results mean the test results show that you have the virus when you don't. A false-positive is rare and thought to happen in less than 1% of results. In some cases, a false-positive result could be caused by a manufacturing error.
related_questions.title: COVID-19 diagnostic testing - Mayo Clinic

related_questions.question: Is it possible to have COVID and test negative on a rapid test?
related_questions.snippet: A negative COVID-19 test means the test did not detect the virus, but this doesn't rule out that you could have an infection. If you used an antigen test, follow FDA recommendations for repeat testing. If you have symptoms: You may have COVID-19 but tested before the virus was detectable.
related_questions.title: Testing for COVID-19 - CDC

related_questions.question: How reliable is the rapid antigen test for COVID?
related_questions.snippet: During November 2022–May 2023, among persons infected with SARS-CoV-2, sensitivity of rapid antigen tests was 47% compared with RT-PCR and 80% compared with viral culture. Antigen tests continue to detect potentially transmissible infection but miss many infections identified by positive RT-PCR test results.
